title: Does a creditor have legal standing to enforce a judgment in state court on real property after the federal bankruptcy court dis
question: charged the debt under chptr. 7? If the lien was placed on the property b4 the filing of the petition under chptr.7, and then the discharge was granted, does the creditor have any legal standing to go after the property after discharge in a state court?
question_tags: Bankruptcy,Bankruptcy court,Judgment lien,Debt,Lien,Bankruptcy and debt,Foreclosure,Real estate and bankruptcy,Real estate,Lawsuits and disputes,Motions,Sued for debt,State court
answers: Sounds like you need to re-open your bk case, and file a motion to avoid the judgment lien. Have your BK attorney do this, if if you didnt use one, you need to now. I changed the category to BK and Debt.

Yes. If you do not avoid a judgment lien in bankruptcy, the lien survives and the creditor can seek recovery out of the property. The discharge only eliminates your personal liability on debts, it does not eliminate the debt itself or a creditors right to collect from someone or something other than you.

If you had a bankruptcy attorney, you should ask him/her whether the lien was avoidable, and if it was, why avoidance was not pursued. The answer may be that you didn't pay for any avoidance actions. It may also be that you didn't disclose the lien. The first is no answer if the lawyer didn't counsel you about it. The second is not a very good answer if the lien is against a property of which your attorney was aware, particularly if it is a local property.

I don't have the bankruptcy code in front of me, and one of the other learned attorneys on Avvo can confirm the following or correct if I am wrong on this, but I believe the statute of limitations on lien avoidance is two years. So, you may be able to reopen your case and avoid the Lien. Get yourself a qualified bankruptcy attorney to help you determine if the lien can be avoided and whether just would be a worthwhile pursuit.
If this is a trust deed, the line remains. There can be no foreclosure, but neither can you escape the lien.
